questions.question: Consider a binary erasure channel with parameter $\epsilon=0.3$ (denoted by $BEC(0.3)$). Suppose that a $n$-length vector, $\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{F}_2^n$, is transmitted through this channel. Which of the following is correct?

answers.a: An erasure at the first position increases the probability of getting an erasure in the second position.
answers.b: The event that $i$ of the $n$ bits are erased has higher probability than the event that $j$ bits are erased, if $j>i$
answers.c: Bits can be flipped or erased in $\boldsymbol{x}$.
answers.d: Exactly $0.3n$ bits will be erased in $\boldsymbol{x}$.

explanations.a: Incorrect answer. The channel models we consider in this lab are all memoryless channels, i.e., noise in each transmitted symbol is independent of noise in other symbols.
explanations.b: Correct Answer! The probability that $i$ bits are erased is $P(i)=\binom{n}{i}0.3^i\times 0.7^{n-i}$. If $i<j$, $P(i)>P(j)$.
explanations.c: Incorrect answer. There are no bit flips possible in the $BEC$ channel model.
explanations.d: Incorrect answer. There is no guarantee that exactly $0.3n$ bits will be erased, simply because the probability of each bit getting erased is $0.3$.
explanations.e: Well, one of them is the correct answer.

questions.question: Consider that we are transmitting some $n$-length bit vector $\boldsymbol{x}$ through a binary symmetric channel with bit flip probability $p=0.9$. What is the probability that exactly the first half of the bits in $\boldsymbol{x}$ are flipped?

explanations.a: Incorrect. There is a non-zero probability that this event can happen.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Observe that the question is giving exactly which of the bits are getting flipped.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Observe that the question is giving exactly which of the bits are getting flipped, and calculate the probability carefully.
explanations.d: Correct! We know that each bit is flipped with probability $0.9$, and any bit is not flipped with probability $0.1$, We have the answer $0.9^{n/2}\times 0.1^{n/2}$ as the right option. Note that there is no binomial coefficient here, as the question specifies exactly which positions are getting flipped.

questions.question: Assume that the input to $BSC(0.3)$ is $(0,1,0,1)$. Consider three possible output sequences (1) $(1,1,0,0)$, (2) $(0,1,1,1)$ and (3) $(0,1,1,0)$. Which of the following is true?

answers.a: (1) and (2) have the same probability of occurrence, but (3) has a higher probability than both
answers.b: (1) and (2) have the same probability of occurrence, but (3) has a lower probability than both
answers.c: (1) and (3) have the same probability of occurrence, but (2) has a higher probability than both

explanations.a: Wrong answer. Note that the bit flip probability is $0.3$. Thus, fewer bit errors occur with higher probability than larger number of bit errors.
explanations.b: Wrong answer. Note that the bit flip probability is $0.3$. Thus, fewer bit errors occur with higher probability than larger number of bit errors.
explanations.c: Correct answer! Vectors (1) and (3) are two bit flips away from the input vector, whereas (2) is just a single bit flip away. Thus, the probabilities of getting either (1) (or (3)) from the given input sequence is $0.3^2\times 0.7^2$, whereas (2) occurs with probability $0.3\times 0.7^3$, given that the input sequence is $(0,1,0,1)$

questions.question: Consider that we are transmitting the sequence $\boldsymbol{x}=(+1,-1,-1)$ through an AWGN channel with noise characteristics $\mathcal{N}(0,0.04)$ (that is, zero-mean and variance = $0.04$). Identify which of the following  output sequence is the most probable one: $\boldsymbol{y_1}=(1.3,-1.1,-1.3)$ (b) $\boldsymbol{y_2}=(1.4,-1.2,-1.1)$

explanations.a: Note that we have to compare the two probabilities $p(\boldsymbol{y_1}|\boldsymbol{x})$ and $p(\boldsymbol{y_2}|\boldsymbol{x})$, and find out which one is higher. By the expression of $p(\boldsymbol{y_i}|\boldsymbol{x})$, we have to find which value among $\sum_{j=1}^3(y_{i,j}-x_j)^2$ for $i=1,2$ is smallest. Now, $\sum_{j=1}^3(y_{1,j}-x_j)^2=0.3^2+0.1^2+0.3^2=0.19$ and $\sum_{j=1}^3(y_{2,j}-x_j)^2=0.4^2+0.2^2+0.1^2=0.21$. Hence, $\boldsymbol{y_1}$ is the more probable output sequence, given that the input was $(+1,-1,-1)$.
